meanings.def: to bring your hand, or an object you are holding, against somebody/something quickly and with force
examples: hit somebody/something I was afraid he was going to hit me.
hit somebody/something with something She hit him with her umbrella.
hit somebody/something in/on something Someone hit him in the face.
hit somebody/something in/on something with something He hit the nail squarely on the head with the hammer.
He hit her with a stick.
He was hit over the head with a broken bottle.
I was so angry, I wanted to hit him.
She didn't hit me very hard.
She hit him in the face.
Their teachers used to hit them with a stick.
I felt like hitting him.
I picked up a pan and hit him over the head with it.
My parents never used to hit me.

meanings.def: to come against something/somebody with force, especially causing damage or injury
examples: hit something/somebody The bus hit the bridge.
The boy was hit by a speeding car.
hit against something/somebody The boat hit against an object under the surface of the water.
The boy was hit by a speeding car.
Someone had knocked a hole in the wall.
The baby was banging the table with his spoon.
The ship struck a rock.
In the darkness I bumped into a chair.
I braked too late, bashing into the car in front.
A taxi almost hit him as he was crossing the street.
She threw a plate at him and narrowly missed hitting him.
I was hit by a falling stone.

meanings.def: to knock a part of your body against something
examples: I must have hit my knee.
hit something on something He hit his head on the low ceiling.
hit something against something As she stood up, she hit her hand against the edge of the table.
I accidentally hit my knee on the desk.
I hit my head on the low doorway.
He fell, hitting his head on the hard stone floor.

meanings.def: to reach and touch a person or thing suddenly and with force
examples: be hit by somebody/something The town was hit by bombs again last night.
He was hit by a sniper.
hit somebody/something Not all the bullets hit their targets.
The grenade will explode as soon as it hits the ground.
He was hit directly in the back.

meanings.def: to bring a bat, etc. against a ball and push it away with force
examples: She hit the ball and ran to first base.
hit something + adv./prep. I hit the ball too hard and it went out of the court.
We've hit our ball over the fence!

meanings.def: to score points by hitting a ball
examples: to hit a home run

meanings.def: to press something such as a button to operate a machine, etc.
examples: Hit the brakes!
He picked up the phone and hit several buttons.
I found the impulse to hit the fast-forward button to be quite overwhelming.
I accidentally hit the wrong key.
Enter your password and then hit ‘Return’.

meanings.def: to have a bad effect on somebody/something
examples: hit (somebody/something) The tax increases will certainly hit the poor.
His death didn't really hit me at first.
A tornado hit on Tuesday night.
Rural areas have been worst hit by the strike.
Spain was one of the hardest hit countries.
it hits somebody + adv. It hit him very hard when Rosie left.
Our department has been badly hit by the cutbacks.
Some businesses have been hit very hard by the rise in interest rates.
The plans could be hit by spending cuts.
Airlines were badly hit by the recession.

meanings.def: to attack somebody/something
examples: We hit the enemy when they least expected it.

meanings.def: to reach a place
examples: Follow this footpath and you'll eventually hit the road.
The President hits town tomorrow.
Traffic was heavy when they hit the main road.
They were making good progress when they hit a wide fast-flowing river.
It'll be two hours before we hit the border.
By the time we hit the city centre, everything was closed.

meanings.def: to reach a particular level
examples: Temperatures hit 40° yesterday.
The euro hit a record low in trading today.
(British English) We hit top form (= played our best) in yesterday’s match.
The film doesn't always hit its targets (= succeed in what it is attempting to do).
He had managed to hit his sales target this month.
Temperatures are expected to hit 30°C tomorrow.

meanings.def: to experience something difficult or unpleasant
examples: We seem to have hit a problem.
Everything was going well but then we hit trouble.

meanings.def: to come suddenly into your mind
examples: hit somebody The idea hit me like a tornado.
it hits somebody I couldn't remember where I'd seen him before, and then it suddenly hit me.
it hits somebody that… That's when it really hit me that we were in deep trouble.

meanings.def: to become widely available for sale
examples: the latest board game to hit the market
to hit the shops/stores/shelves
Her shocking autobiography is about to hit the streets.

meanings.def: to be an important item of news in the media
examples: He always manages to grab the headlines.
The hospital hit the headlines when a number of suspicious deaths occurred.
The story was important enough to make the headlines.

meanings.def: to be very successful
examples: The band has hit big in the US.

meanings.def: if a plan, somebody’s career, etc. hits the buffers, it suddenly stops being successful
examples: The former tennis star’s comeback trail hit the buffers yesterday when she lost in straight sets.

meanings.def: to fall to the ground
to affect somebody very deeply
examples: The business over the lawsuit had really knocked her for six.

meanings.def: to start doing something and continue very quickly and successfully
to go to bed
examples: I decided to hit the sack and have an early night.

meanings.def: if a remark, etc. hits/strikes home, it has a strong effect on somebody, in a way that makes them realize what the true facts of a situation are
examples: Her face went pale as his words hit home.

meanings.def: to be very obvious to somebody
used to tell somebody to start doing something, such as playing music
examples: Hit it, Louis!

meanings.def: to have a good friendly relationship with somebody
examples: We hit it off straight away.

meanings.def: to make or win a lot of money quickly and unexpectedly
to succeed/fail in achieving or guessing something
examples: He blushed furiously and Robyn knew she had hit the mark.
The film misses the mark because it just isn't believable.

meanings.def: to say something that is exactly right
to mention a subject that makes somebody feel angry, upset, embarrassed, etc.
examples: You touched a raw nerve when you mentioned his first wife.
My remarks about divorce had unwittingly touched a raw nerve.
The article struck a raw nerve as it revived unpleasant memories.

meanings.def: to suddenly be in a successful situation, especially one that makes you rich
examples: The band really hit pay dirt with their last album.

meanings.def: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion
examples: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

meanings.def: to start a journey
examples: The following spring I hit the road.

meanings.def: to suddenly become very angry
if something hits the spot it does exactly what it should do
to begin to do something with confidence and at a good speed after a slow, uncertain start
examples: After a nervous start, he finally hit his stride in the second set.
The team took time to hit stride.
The show finally hit its stride in the second season.

meanings.def: to reach a point when you cannot continue or make any more progress
examples: We hit a wall and we weren't scoring.
I’ve hit a wall with my marathon training.
What do you do when you hit the wall at work?

meanings.def: to continue to hurt somebody when they are already defeated
to affect somebody where they will feel it most
to hit the wooden frame of the goal in the game of football (soccer), instead of scoring a goal
examples: She hit the woodwork twice before scoring.

meanings.def: to be so surprised by something that you do not know how to react
when somebody in authority finds out about something bad or wrong that somebody has done
examples: When the shit hits the fan, I don't want to be here.

meanings.def: an act of hitting somebody/something with your hand or with an object held in your hand
examples: Give it a good hit.
He made the winning hit.

meanings.def: an occasion when something that has been thrown, fired, etc. at an object reaches that object; the fact of being hit by something
examples: We finished the first round with a score of two hits and six misses.
One of the tanks took a direct hit.
The aircraft suffered seven hits in the raid.
Few structures can withstand a hit from a speeding car.
hit on something Enemy planes scored a hit on a supply ship.

meanings.def: a person or thing that is very popular
examples: He's just about to star in the hit musical, ‘Chicago’.
a hit show/comedy
Her new series is a smash hit.
a big/huge hit
The duo were a real hit in last year's show.
The film scored a major international hit.
a hit with somebody The films have proved a hit with older audiences.
The series has been a big hit with children.
He shot to fame in the hit TV show, ‘Friends’.
The fast-fit centres have proved a hit with motorists.
The film was a hit for him in 2008.

meanings.def: a successful pop song or record
examples: They are about to release an album of their greatest hits.
She played all her old hits.
a hit single/song
She had a hit with ‘Only You’.
This is her third Number One hit record.
She is here to promote her latest chart hit.

meanings.def: an occasion on which a web page is displayed or a file is downloaded from the internet
examples: Our website is getting a lot of hits from the USA.
How many hits did you get?

meanings.def: the fact of finding an item of data that matches a search
examples: The search generated 1 848 hits.

meanings.def: an amount of an illegal drug that is taken at one time
examples: a hit of cocaine/heroin

meanings.def: a violent crime or murder
to be liked very much by somebody when they first meet you
examples: You’ve made a big hit with Bill.

meanings.def: to be damaged or badly affected by something
examples: The airline industry took a hit last year.
